metadata.title: The Use of Decision Modelling to Inform Timely Policy Decisions on Cardiac Resource Capacity during the COVID-19 Pandemic

body_text.text: First, in the initial crisis phase, in a worst case scenario, we showed that the potential number of waitlist 82 related cardiac deaths would be orders of magnitude less than those who would die of COVID-19 if 83 critical cardiac care resources were diverted to the care of COVID-19 patients. Second, with better local 84 epidemiology data, we predicted that across five regions of Ontario, there may be insufficient resources 85 to resume all elective outpatient cardiac procedures. Our 109 overall goals were to better understand the consequences of initially curtailing and subsequently 110 resuming cardiac procedures during the pandemic, and to be able to provide timely, data-111 informed predictions to facilitate policy decisions. We provide an example of how such 112 modelling was used through the arc of the COVID-19 pandemic in Ontario, through the initial 113 crisis phase of the pandemic with substantial unknowns, a second phase with local epidemiology 114 data available, and then finally the recovery phase. The cardiac modeling group consisted of a multidisciplinary team of graduate students, clinician-119 scientists, and academics with expertise in cardiology/cardiac surgery, infectious disease, and 120 advanced decision analytic modeling. This is an important point given the concern for 203 multiple waves of the pandemic in the absence of a vaccine for COVID-19. 5 In this first response 204 to the pandemic, the public health mandate was prioritized over other concerns; we recognize 205 that in hindsight, resources were left unused in Ontario. This reinforces the need for prediction 206 models to be improved for the next phase of the pandemic, such that subsequent policy decisions 207 are improved and spillover impacts on non-COVID-19 care is reduced 208 conditions, such as cardiac disease, result in significant sequelae; these spillover impacts are also 246 critical consequences of the pandemic. FIGREF1.text: evolving COVID-19 pandemic has necessitated anticipatory policy decision-making 93 in the presence of uncertainty. In the initial crisis phase of the pandemic, there were substantial 94 concerns that available healthcare resources would be overwhelmed. In Ontario, the Ministry of 95 Health and Long-Term Care (MOHTLC) issued a directive on March 16 th , 2020, to all acute care 96 hospitals to halt non-essential procedures in anticipation for a potential surge in COVID-19 97 patients. This included scheduled outpatient cardiac surgical and interventional procedures that 98 required the use of intensive care units, ventilators, and skilled critical care personnel and was 99 broadly consistent with early guidance from the Canadian Cardiovascular Society and later 100 recommendations from the Canadian Association of Interventional Cardiology and the Canadian 101 Society of Cardiac Surgeons. 1,2 While socially responsible, the magnitude of the immediate and 102 long-term consequences of delaying cardiac care is not known. The use of simulation modelling 103 allows one to balance the potential needs of COVID-19 patients against that of delaying non-104 COVID-19 care by explicitly estimating resource utilization and constraints in conjunction with 105 predictions in COVID-19 infection rates and hospitalizations. The modeling was performed iteratively to 124 contend with the rapid evolution of the pandemic and the model output was assessed at biweekly 125 meetings with stakeholders to inform policy decisions. 126 127 A parallel, open-cohort, dynamic individual-patient-level microsimulation (COvid-19 Resource 128 Estimator, CORE) model to predict hospital resource utilization of COVID-19 patients 129 presenting daily to hospital from the perspective of the Ontario healthcare system was created by 130 researchers and clinicians at the University of Toronto's Covid-19-MC team. 3 An interactive 131 version of the model is publicly available [https://www.covid-19-mc.ca/]. In this model, a daily 132 influx of symptomatic COVID-19 patients (based on patterns of predicted epidemiology at that 133 time) entered the hospital system to compete for a pool of fixed healthcare resources. By running 134 the model over the specified time horizon of the pandemic, this model allowed for the estimation 135 of daily ward, ICU, and ventilators use at the provincial level over the course of the pandemic. 136 Findings from the CORE model were used to set policy and inform technical press briefings by 137 Ontario Health, the MOHLTC and the Ontario Premier's office. 138 139 The CORE model was then adapted to include a cardiac submodule (Figure 1). We chose to 140 examine three areas of cardiovascular medicine with a poor natural history when left untreated: 141 severe symptomatic valvular heart disease requiring open valve surgery or transcatheter aortic 142 valve replacement (TAVR), advanced coronary artery disease requiring revascularization with 143 coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) or percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), and 144 arrhythmia disorders requiring ablation therapy or implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD) device 145 implantation. We did not include heart transplantation, mechanical circulatory support, or cardiac 146 catheterization procedures outside of PCI. 147 148 Our work took place over 3 phases. In the initial "crisis" phase of the pandemic, we examined 149 the impact of increasing number of COVID-19 patients under various epidemiological scenarios 150 (expected scenario, worst case, "Italy scenario", best case, "South Korea scenario"), 3 entering 151 hospitals, requiring the use of cardiac care resources, such as dedicated cardiac ICU and ward 152 beds, and thereby displacing non-COVID-19 cardiac patients. We used epidemiology scenarios 153 from other countries, as that in Ontario was evolving and not known. Nonetheless, pandemic 154 planning was required and could not be delayed till the Ontario epidemiology became apparent. 155 The model estimated unplanned cardiovascular admissions and waitlist mortality for the three 156 modelled cardiovascular disease states based on the published literature. 4 The second phase of 157 our model examined the impact of a policy decision to further curtail elective outpatient 158 procedures (April 5 th , 2020) on an increasing waitlist as the Ontario epidemiology became 159 apparent. The third and on-going phase of the model is recovery, as the Ontario COVID-19 160 pandemic is beyond its peak and currently in a plateau. Our work now focusses on the time 161 required to clear the backlog of outpatient cardiac procedures by modeling various scenarios of 162 the healthcare system's capacity to perform cardiac procedures relative to baseline volume prior 163 to the COVID-19 pandemic. FIGREF5.text: Summary of modeling implications for policy making 210 211Pandemic planning requires nimble decision making in the face of substantial unknowns. The 212consequences of delaying decisions until local epidemiology data is known with certainty can be 213 catastrophic, as seen in jurisdictions such as Italy and New York, where the systems were 214overwhelmed. Modelling provides decision makers with a credible envelope of potential future 215 scenarios, to aid with difficult decisions. The COVID-19 pandemic in Ontario followed this 216 process. Initial worse case scenarios required an immediate and almost complete shift of the 217 healthcare system to care for those critically ill with the virus, at the exclusion of all but the most 218 gravely ill non-COVID-19 patients. Although reasonable in the short term, once local data was 219 known, it required a strategy shift. Understanding the impact of such a policy is crucial in order 220 to understand the cardiac consequences of the decision and to estimate the size of the potential 221 backlog of cardiovascular procedures so that decisions about resumption of activity can be 222 informed. A unique aspect of this model is that COVID-19 patients and cardiovascular patients 223 compete for shared resources. In essence, this explicitly models the fact that policy decisions 224 regarding cardiac patients cannot be made in isolation from the reality of the pandemic and the 225 needs of COVID-19 patients. are important limitations in decision analytic modeling that must be addressed. First, 230 accurate modeling depends on several factors: a model structure that closely resembles reality, 231 reasonable model assumptions, and relevant inputs. We acknowledge that not every possible 232 scenario can be modeled and there may be important non-fatal outcomes that are relevant to 233 cardiovascular patients that are inadequately represented. Another limitation is that models may 234 be complex and difficult to understand without specialized knowledge or understanding of 235 modeling software. To address concerns about model transparency, we believe such models 236 should be public and to that end, we have provided a detailed supplemental appendix to describe 237 the model structure and assumptions. modelling is not designed to predict the future, but rather to provide decision makers 242 with a credible envelope of possible scenarios. As witnessed in other jurisdictions, in a 243 pandemic, failure to make anticipatory decisions can have dire consequences. FIGREF7.text: A schematic of the COVID-19 Resource Estimator (CORE) decision analytic model and the cardiac disease submodule that includes catheter based procedures (electrophysiology procedures, transcatheter aortic valve replacement, percutaneous coronary interventions) and open surgical procedures (coronary artery bypass grafting, valve surgery). Increasing numbers of COVID-19 patients and a steady number of elective cardiac outpatients compete for critical care resources. The stop sign denotes potential capacity constraints for resources. The model was adapted to measure incremental change in cardiac waitlist, consumption of critical care resources throughout the pandemic, and death while awaiting procedures for the entire province of Ontario and five geographical health regions using historic referral data, real time procedural data, and real time resource ICU and ward bed capacity data.

FIGREF8.text: Examples of different model outputs from the CORE model and cardiac submodule. A. Base case scenario for resource consumption by COVID-19 patients in Ontario based on what was known about COVID-19 epidemiology in late March (adapted from www.covid-19-mc.ca/). B. Estimated number of elective patient deaths over time with the cessation of elective cardiac procedures in early April followed by gradual resumption of procedures in mid-April to early May. C. The potential depletion of cardiac critical care resources if 75% of cardiac beds are reserved for COVID-19 patients and cardiac procedures are performed at 100% capacity. D. The predicted growth in waitlist as a consequence of holding all elective outpatient cardiac procedures for one week in April followed by gradual resumption of procedural activity.
